subject: Re: [junit] How do you test your Java EE 5 applications?
msgSnippet: I have given the advice to extract your businesslogic into pojos and write regular unit-tests for them many times. I m currently doing some basic EJB 3.0
messageBody:
I have given the advice to extract your businesslogic into pojos and
write regular unit-tests for them many times.

I'm currently doing some basic EJB 3.0 testing and I found that most
of the issues I had with the previous specification are gone. The new
session beans are just pojos with dependency injection and the EJB
stuff is merely visible as anotations.

So I guess I'm saying I don't feel that there is as much benefit of
extracting the business-logic of the session beans as pojos anymore
since the session-beans are in effect pojos already (with
annotations). And can be tested with regular unit tests as they are,
so why complicate things?

Of course it's possible that there are issues I have yet to run in to
and that I'm viewing this from the sunny side but so far so good.

What I would like to do though (I develop in geronimo) is to be able
to start up open-ejb inside some acceptance-tests. It looked like it
could be done from open-ejbs site but I have not gotten around to that
yet. I still need to deploy to a server sometimes so maybe the added
benefit of in-test containers are marginal or negative.

I'm also interested in any issues people may have had with testing EJB
3.0 stuff, it would be nice to know what to watch out for before I'm
in the middle of it :)

Just my 2 cents...


On Jan 23, 2008 9:25 PM, Nat Pryce <nat.pryce@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> On 23/01/2008, Kent Larsson <kent.larsson@...> wrote:
> |> One approach I've heard is to have the session beans as dumb forwarders
> > of requests to normal objects. And implement the actual business logic
> > in normal Java classes.
>
> This is how I do it and it works very well. It enforces a clear
> separation between application logic, which is written as normal
> object-oriented code, and the J2EE technology. That keeps all the
> awkward design issues of the J2EE framework well outside the
> application. The classes that refer to the J2EE framework are just an
> adapter layer between the transaction management of the app container
> and the objects of the application itself.
>
> It means that you can easily test the application code in plain JUnit
> (and jMock).
>
> You'll need end-to-end tests to ensure that the adapter layer works as
> expected. But you have those already, I expect.
>
> --Nat
